bibl.title: Letter from J. N. Kenealy to Philip Showalter Hench, August 5, 1946

div1.p: Kenealy informs Hench about several people who had some connection with yellow fever or the Canal Zone in the early 1900s. He writes that his parents lived across the street from the Ancon Hospital fever wards. His father was in charge of the hospital mess and commissaries, beginning in 1904.

div1.head: Letter from J. N. Kenealy to Philip Showalter Hench, August 5, 1946
div1.opener:
Box 1437, Balboa, C. Z.
August 5, 1946.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
102-110 Second, Ave. S. W.,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your two articles on Yellow Fever Dr. Hewitt is sending
me are not yet arrived but I have already promised them to Corrigan and
he has promised me to send you a sketch of his experiences.

Joseph A. Corrigan, Sr. address; Gamboa, C. Z., had yellow
fever in February '05, line of duty, a Sanitary Inspector fighting the
mosquitoes at the time. He remained at that work through the Construc-
tion period - went to the States and later in like capacity was with the
United Fruit Co, covering all of their tropical holdings - he was associ-
ated with Dr's Roland Connor, Deeks, etc. He has probably had a more
varied experience in sanitation than any of the old group. At present
is retired and living in Gamboa.

Miss Sarah De la Pena, stenographer in District Court, Ancon,
is one of three or more children of Luis De la Pena (no middle initial).
She says that to her knowledge her father never had yellow fever. That he
was with Gorgas in Cuba, arrived here on that famous first boat, June 28,
1904, carrying the first American Staff of Ancon Hospital and the Health
Department. He later served with the American Red Cross in Europe, Serbia.
Wound up as Chief Health Officer in Corinto, Nicarragua, where he was as-
sasinated in February 1918: no pension allowed widow “as not during working
hours”. She says she has much of her father's files, pictures, letters
from Col. Gorgas and other correspondence. Will be only too glad to co-
operate in any way possible to further your work. Her address: Box 1311,
Ancon, C. Z.

Charles Stockleberg, died here about a year ago was another
man who survived the fever here in Panama. Mrs. Frank B. Coyle, Balboa
Heights, C. Z., as sister-in-law, could give you any information covering
his case, if you are interested. At the time of infection he was a Fore-
man of Plumbing for the Commission, lived to a ripe old age and acquired
a wonderful reputation in the service of the Panaman Government, was honored
with one of their highest decorations. In his case as in Corrigan's there
were no after effects inpairing their efficiency or worth.

John Corrigan, Sr., brother of Joe, also a Sanitary Inspector
continuosly thru his Canal employment until retirement was veteran of the
Spanish American War, but as to whether Cuba or the Philippines or of pre-
vious connections with Col. Gorgas, I do not know. Joe will probably in-
clude him in his report to you as I asked him to specify as well as he
could all associates, places etc., which might bring you a new angle -
I've given up hopes of telling you people something new. In this connection,
J. J. McGuigan, Ancon, C. Z., is married to some distant cousin of the Col-
onels, ex-spanish war man and undoubtedly possesses a vast fund of knowledge
anecdotes, etc. on the Colonel and many of his official family. He re-
tired as District Attorney for the Zone.

The old Ancon Hospital was far prettier than the grand scene
it presents today. The French knew their landscaping and the wooden build-
ings, set in narrow winding roads, to we “Gringos” was something knew.
The old fever wards were located on the site now occupied by the Board of
Health Laboratory, back in )('09 or '10, the wards were converted to the
Eye & Ear Clinic, Dr. Reeder, now in Panama Hospital, succeeded Lister,
“Pop” Reeder is still going strong.

My parents occupied the small cottage across the street from the
fever wards. When a big man was dying my mother would have to move out
for the several hours involved - she used to go up and visit at the Nurses
Quarters. Corrigan, Stockleberg were both small men, as I remember the
strictly non-professional story was: “a big man never stood a chance”. The
forced labor of a big man gasping for breath that only a good distance
could shut out.

In mulling these things over the thought strikes me that Colonel
Gorgas was most happy in his selection of that first boat load. They were
a picked group that through former like experiences and contacts were able
to roll along at a high degree of efficiency from the start. One instance,
my father, was just retired from the Army as a Commissary Sergeant,
out of Puerto Rico: taking over the Hospital Mess and Commissaries, market-
ing in Panama: he hadn't been away from like work over a period of six weeks.
The thought struck me that if you could get the passenger list of that first
boat load - it would be hard to picture a better grouping for the job ahead.

As a simple matter of giving you a couple of addresses * I appear
to have taken more than words than was called for - I look forward with
pleasure to reading your articles and it was nice of Dr. Hewitt to send
them.
